page.title: 01LONG ASHTON & SURROUNDINGS
page.content: Our 12 square kilometers lie to the south west of Bristol. The area has much countryside. Much of the land has lush grass which is used for dairying. However, some is arable, where wheat and other crops can be grown. The main feature of the area is the village of Long Ashton itself, with a population of 6000. Long Ashton lies on the side of a valley, stretching up the hill to the north. At the top of the hill there are plantations of trees. Long Ashton is very much a village, but could quite easily have become a part of Bristol. It remains independent because of Ashton Court, once a large private estate, now publicly-owned. At one time Long Ashton was on the main route from Weston-super-Mare to Bristol, but in 1969 a by-pass was built to divert the traffic, making the village less busy.
